channel.title: yudel tweets
channel.description: A feed of recent tweets from yudel.

item.description: Graffiti in Manhattan. Hebrew for “Never Again” in Ukraine colors. https://t.co/7NuokPWr3I
Evergreen tweet. https://t.co/4i4QTE1rDT
@ayeletw Wonder what the dead man’s BAC was.

@aschwortz @TheRaDR I think both were a factor here. One can rationally believe in a global Jewish conspiracy. To think that it can be stopped with your hammer is crazy.
@aschwortz @TheRaDR That said, I would like to see a lot more investigative work on how people who commit hate crimes have bought into their bigoted beliefs. What are the networks by which they propagate?
@TheRaDR Here’s a local case of anti-trans antisemitic conspiracy thinking erupting into antisemitic violence. https://t.co/JeRPmpfFkT
https://t.co/lJsiYGpF3i
@datadivajf I admire her piety in keeping 16 days of Hanukkah.
@DBashIdeas Speaking of morally broke university systems, don’t forget the role of this Supreme Court case in disempowering faculty. https://t.co/hUJQCOuGH4
@jh_swanson Republican Speaker of the Republican-controlled House. Name the party. https://t.co/Kg5tfV9eh6
How worried should I be about running a 2008 release of jquery (jquery-1.2.6.min.js) on a legacy web site?
https://t.co/TWKWI0n6F3
@trekonomics Oy. I’ve seen them do good Jewish Studies work. Maybe they’re out of their depth when it comes to science — wouldn’t be the first time.
@trekonomics If you want to write it in English, Marginalia might be interested. I know people who know people there. https://t.co/nZ147f6Qdh

@trekonomics There is no way that French Catholic theology and its relationship to politics, aesthetics, and architecture can be more niche than, say, the religious practices of the remaining 850 Samaritans. https://t.co/RXiP7ni1vU
@trekonomics It’s fiction, but this series of feminist bicycle science fiction or fantasy anthologies totally changed my definition of what is a viable publishing niche. https://t.co/DnLQqu0ISi
@trekonomics Democrats deliver: Overdoses are no longer America’s leading cause of unnecessary deaths!
@trekonomics Not going to “like” this tweet until you decide to turn it into a separate essay. Which would be helpful for book promotion, if I may put on my publisher’s hat.
I’d love to see a comparative reading of this, contemporary haredi miracle working, and the situation in American Pentecostal Christianity. https://t.co/desAXNasST
@lavietidhar Frankly, as long as people buy books, who cares what people do with them?
@froomkin @nytopinion Here’s some questions from the left I’d love to see them address. https://t.co/T8iks5WfYC

Given that land in the American colonies was given out in part based on how many slaves colonists brought with them, immigrating to America in the colonial era strongly selected for those without moral qualms, and being an established 18th century landholder more so. https://t.co/jAKmv2R7OC
Founding fathers may have been typical of their fellow children of the initial generation of slaver colonists in their moral judgements, but that’s hardly a fair reflection of the state of 18th century moral philosophy.

@prof_dainy @MisfitTorah The great thing about having ancestors who passed through the bottleneck of 19th century West Point, Georgia, is we know our sixth cousins because they’re also our fourth and second cousins.

Incidentally, how come no one has made the connection between the covid mageifa (plague) and the infiltration of Orthodox Judaism by the MAGA movement? Seems more solid than blaming earthquakes on Jewish cartoonists. https://t.co/w93BpHGly8
@scalzi A quarter of the way through. I do hope there’s an explanation for your violation of pretty explicit internationally agreed upon secrecy protocols.

Oh, I loved my Smith Corona. https://t.co/y5dgnt9Drk
Not this pinwheel, though. A basic model somewhat like this with ink and and eraser cartridges my parents bought me around the time of my bar mitzvah. By the time a key broke a decade later, I had moved on to my Osborne. https://t.co/PUb8eQJmZG
